docs.title: datafun-06-eda
docs.text: Welcome to the Car Crashes EDA Project documentation!

docs.title: Author
docs.text: Tammy Mims

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
This project demonstrates exploratory data analysis (EDA) skills using:

  • GitHub for version control
  • Jupyter notebooks for interactive analysis
  • pandas for data manipulation
  • Seaborn and Matplotlib for visualization
  • Statistical analysis techniques

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: Create a custom exploratory data analysis (EDA) project using GitHub, Jupyter, pandas, Seaborn, and other popular data analytics tools to analyze U.S. state-level car crash statistics.

docs.title: Repository
docs.text: GitHub Repository: tmims71-ctrl/datafun-06-eda

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Project Setup - Installation and environment setup
  • Dataset Information - About the car crashes dataset
  • Notebook Analysis - Details about the EDA notebook

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• ✅ Clean, well-documented code
  • ✅ Comprehensive EDA workflow
  • ✅ Multiple visualization types
  • ✅ Statistical analysis and correlation studies
  • ✅ Clear data storytelling with markdown narratives
  • ✅ Fully executed notebook with outputs

docs.title: Technologies Used
docs.text:
• Python 3.11+
  • JupyterLab - Interactive notebook environment
  • pandas - Data manipulation and analysis
  • Seaborn - Statistical data visualization
  • Matplotlib - Plotting library
  • NumPy - Numerical computations
  • uv - Fast Python package manager
  • pytest - Testing framework
  • ruff - Code formatting
  • mkdocs - Documentation generator

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The car_crashes dataset is a built-in dataset from the Seaborn library containing U.S. state-level statistics on fatal automobile accidents and related factors.

docs.title: Source
docs.text:
• Origin: Seaborn built-in datasets
  • GitHub: https://github.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/blob/master/car_crashes.csv
  • Local Copy: data/car_crashes.csv

docs.title: Dataset Statistics
docs.text: Property Value Rows 51 Columns 8 Missing Values 0 Duplicate Rows 0

docs.title: Column Descriptions
docs.text: Column Type Description abbrev string State abbreviation (e.g., AL, AK, AZ) total float Number of fatal collisions per billion miles driven speeding float Percentage of fatal collisions where speeding was a factor alcohol float Percentage of fatal collisions involving alcohol impairment not_distracted float Percentage of fatal collisions where the driver was not distracted no_previous float Percentage of drivers involved in fatal collisions with no previous accidents ins_premium float Car insurance premiums (annual, in dollars) ins_losses float Losses incurred by insurance companies for collisions per insured driver (annual, in dollars)

docs.title: Completeness
docs.text:
✅ No missing values - All 51 states have complete data across all 8 columns.

✅ No duplicates - Each state appears exactly once in the dataset.

docs.title: Data Types
docs.text: All numeric columns are stored as float64 types, while the state abbreviation is stored as object (string) type.

docs.title: Summary Statistics
docs.text:
Total Fatal Collisions (per billion miles): - Mean: ~15.79 - Std Dev: ~4.12 - Min: ~5.90 - Max: ~23.90 - Range: ~18.00

These statistics show significant variability in crash rates across U.S. states.

docs.title: Usage in Analysis
docs.text:
This dataset is ideal for:

  • Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA): Understanding patterns and distributions
  • Correlation Studies: Identifying relationships between crash factors
  • Comparative Analysis: Comparing states on safety metrics
  • Visualization Practice: Creating charts, plots, and heatmaps
  • Statistical Analysis: Computing means, medians, standard deviations

docs.title: Why This Dataset?
docs.text:
The car_crashes dataset was chosen because:

  1. ✅ Clean: No missing values or data quality issues
  2. ✅ Manageable Size: 51 rows is perfect for learning
  3. ✅ Relevant: Traffic safety is an important public policy topic
  4. ✅ Multiple Variables: 8 columns provide rich analysis opportunities
  5. ✅ Pre-installed: Available directly through Seaborn
  6. ✅ Well-documented: Clear variable definitions and source

docs.title: In Python
docs.text:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd

# Load from Seaborn
car_df = sns.load_dataset('car_crashes')

# Or load from local CSV
car_df = pd.read_csv('../data/car_crashes.csv')

docs.title: Preview
docs.text:
# View first few rows
car_df.head()

# Get dataset info
car_df.info()

# View summary statistics
car_df.describe()

docs.title: tmims_eda.ipynb
docs.text: The main analysis notebook is located at: notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb

docs.title: Notebook Structure
docs.text: The notebook is organized into 10 main sections that guide you through a complete exploratory data analysis workflow.

docs.title: Section 0: Introduction
docs.text:
Intro to Jupyter Notebooks - Basic notebook usage and keyboard shortcuts - Cell types (Markdown vs Code) - Kernel selection guidance

Intro to EDA - Purpose and goals of exploratory data analysis - Understanding data structure, quality, and relationships

docs.title: Section 1: Project Setup and Imports
docs.text:
All necessary libraries are imported at the top:

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Display options are configured for optimal data viewing.

docs.title: Section 2: Load the Data
docs.text:
The car_crashes dataset is loaded from the local CSV file:

car_df = pd.read_csv("../data/car_crashes.csv")

Initial data preview with .head() displays the first few rows.

docs.title: Section 3: Inspect Data Shape and Structure
docs.text: Key checks performed: - Shape: 51 rows × 8 columns - Data Types: .info() shows column types and non-null counts - Column Names: List all variable names

docs.title: Section 4: Data Quality Checks
docs.text:
Quality validation includes: - Missing Values: Check for null values per column - Duplicates: Verify uniqueness of records

Result: ✅ No missing values or duplicates found

docs.title: Section 5: Create Clean View
docs.text:
A clean DataFrame is created by removing any rows with missing values (though none exist in this dataset):

car_clean = car_df.dropna()

This ensures downstream analysis uses only complete records.

docs.title: Section 6: Descriptive Statistics
docs.text:
Statistical summary generated using: - Pandas: .describe() for all numeric columns - NumPy: Manual calculation of mean, std dev, min, max, and range for specific columns

Key findings: - Mean total crashes: ~15.79 per billion miles - Significant variation across states (std dev ~4.12)

docs.title: Section 7: Correlation Matrix
docs.text:
Correlation Analysis: - Compute correlation matrix between all numeric variables - Visualize with Seaborn heatmap showing correlation coefficients

Key Insights: - Identifies which factors are most strongly associated with total crashes - Reveals relationships between contributing factors (speeding, alcohol, distraction)

docs.title: Section 8: Visualizations
docs.text:
Scatter Plot: Speeding vs Total Crashes - Shows relationship between speeding percentage and crash rates - Helps identify if speeding is a major factor

Histogram: Alcohol-Related Crash Distribution - Displays frequency distribution of alcohol involvement - Includes KDE (kernel density estimate) curve for smooth distribution

docs.title: Section 8b: Additional Charts
docs.text:
Pairplot: - Matrix of scatter plots between all numeric variables - Diagonals show distributions - Reveals multivariate relationships at a glance

Bar Chart: Top 15 States by Total Crashes - Ranks states with highest fatal collision rates - Highlights geographic variations in traffic safety

Boxplot: Distribution of Numeric Metrics - Shows spread, median, quartiles, and outliers for all variables - Useful for identifying unusual states or extreme values

docs.title: Section 9: Reminder
docs.text: A note to ensure all cells are executed before saving and pushing to GitHub, ensuring outputs are captured.

docs.title: Section 10: Conclusion
docs.text:
Key Findings: 1. Dataset is clean and reliable (no missing values/duplicates) 2. Significant state-to-state variability in crash rates 3. Correlation analysis reveals relationships between factors 4. Visual analysis identifies patterns and outliers

Implications: - Region-specific traffic safety interventions may be more effective - High-risk states could benefit from targeted programs

Next Steps: - Incorporate additional variables (population density, infrastructure, weather) - Deeper analysis of state-level traffic safety laws - Predictive modeling for crash risk factors

docs.title: Execution Results
docs.text:
All 26 code cells have been successfully executed with outputs including:

  • ✅ Text output (print statements, statistics)
  • ✅ DataFrames (tables with data)
  • ✅ Visualizations (PNG images of plots)

docs.title: In VS Code
docs.text:
1. Open notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb
  2. Select the .venv Python interpreter
  3. Click "Run All" or execute cells individually

docs.title: In JupyterLab
docs.text: uv run jupyter lab notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb

docs.title: Best Practices Demonstrated
docs.text: ✅ Single Imports Section - All libraries imported at the top ✅ Markdown Documentation - Each section has explanatory text ✅ Logical Flow - Analysis proceeds from basic to complex ✅ Multiple Visualizations - Various chart types for different insights ✅ Statistical Rigor - Descriptive stats and correlation analysis ✅ Data Quality Checks - Explicit validation of data integrity ✅ Clear Conclusions - Summary of findings and implications ✅ Professional Presentation - Clean code, clear narratives

docs.title: Visualizations Created
docs.text:
1. Correlation Heatmap - Shows relationships between all variables
  2. Scatter Plot - Speeding vs total crashes
  3. Histogram with KDE - Distribution of alcohol-related crashes
  4. Pairplot - Comprehensive multivariate view
  5. Bar Chart - Top states by crash rate
  6. Boxplot - Distribution comparison across metrics

docs.title: Statistical Methods Applied
docs.text:
• Descriptive statistics (mean, median, std dev, min, max, range)
  • Correlation analysis (Pearson correlation coefficients)
  • Distribution analysis (histograms, KDE)
  • Outlier detection (boxplots)

docs.title: Data Story
docs.text:
The notebook tells a coherent story about U.S. traffic safety:

  1. Setup: Introduce the problem and data
  2. Validate: Ensure data quality
  3. Explore: Examine distributions and relationships
  4. Visualize: Create informative plots
  5. Conclude: Summarize findings and suggest actions

This demonstrates professional data analysis skills and effective communication.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • Git
  • VS Code (recommended) or another editor
  • uv package manager (or pip)

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/tmims71-ctrl/datafun-06-eda.git
cd datafun-06-eda

docs.title: 2. Create and Activate Virtual Environment
docs.text:
Using uv (recommended):

uv sync

Alternatively, using pip and venv:

py -m venv .venv
.\.venv\Scripts\activate
py -m pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
py -m pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt --timeout 100

docs.title: 3. Verify Installation
docs.text:
Test that packages are installed correctly:

uv run pytest --cov=src --cov-report=term-missing

docs.title: 4. Run Code Formatting
docs.text:
Format Python code with ruff:

uv run ruff format .

docs.title: Open the Notebook in VS Code
docs.text:
1. Open the notebook file: notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb
  2. Select the Python interpreter from your .venv
  3. Select the kernel associated with your project virtual environment
  4. Run cells individually or use "Run All"

docs.title: Run JupyterLab (Alternative)
docs.text:
To open JupyterLab in your browser:

jupyter lab notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb

Or with uv:

uv run jupyter lab notebooks/tmims_eda.ipynb

docs.title: Build MkDocs Site
docs.text: uv run mkdocs build

docs.title: Serve Documentation Locally
docs.text:
uv run mkdocs serve

Then open your browser to: http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Deploy to GitHub Pages
docs.text: uv run mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: uv sync fails
docs.text:
If you encounter compiler errors, remove version pins and delete uv.lock:

Remove-Item uv.lock
uv sync

docs.title: Kernel not found
docs.text: Make sure you've selected the correct Python interpreter in VS Code and installed ipykernel in your virtual environment.

docs.title: Package import errors
docs.text:
Ensure your virtual environment is activated and all packages are installed:

uv sync
